Author:ErikWDev (Erik W. Gren)
Copyright:2021-2022

The easyess module aims to provive a basic ECS setup for nim with macros and templates in order to abstract away the implementation details with minimal effect on performance.

easyess is still under active development. For a more complete, mature and flexible setup I recommend the package polymorph.

While the name easyess might seem terrible for searchability (and it is..), I still argue its usefulness. You can nom create a file named ecs.nim within which you can do import esasyess and call createECS() which generates a bunch of code that is exported from the file. You can then simply import ecs within your other modules without any name conflict with this package.

Note on Docs

In order to show all functions, procs, templates and macros that are generated in the end by the createECS() macro, these docs were generated with the code below present.

import easyess

comp:
  type
    ExampleComponent = object
      exampleData: int
    
    DocumentationComponent = tuple
      otherData: float
    
    ExampleFlag = enum
      efOne
      efTwo
    
    ExampleID = uint16

sys [ExampleComponent, DocumentationComponent, ExampleFlag], "exampleSystems":
  func exampleSystem(item: ExampleItem) =
    let (ecs, entity) = item
    
    discard exampleComponent.exampleData
    discard documentationComponent.otherData
    discard exampleFlag

sys [ExampleID], "exampleSystems":
  func exampleIDSystem(item: ExampleIDItem) =
    discard exampleID

createECS(ECSConfig(maxEntities: 100))

Types

BaseIDType = uint16
The integer kind used for IDs. Currently uint16 is used which allows for 65 535 entities alive simultaniously. If more are required (or less), change this type manually within your project. 
ECS = ref object
  nextID*: Entity
  when not false:
      usedLabels: Table[string, bool]
      ecsInspectLabelContainer: array[100, string]

  signatureContainer*: array[100, Signature]
  exampleComponentContainer*: array[100, ExampleComponent]
  documentationComponentContainer*: array[100, DocumentationComponent]
  exampleFlagContainer*: array[100, ExampleFlag]
  exampleIDContainer*: array[100, ExampleID]

ECSComponentKind = enum
  ckExists, ckExampleComponent, ckDocumentationComponent, ckExampleFlag,
  ckExampleID
ECSConfig = object
  maxEntities*: int
A configureation that can be specified statically to createECS to determine the settings of the ECS 
Entity = distinct BaseIDType
Entities are simply distinct IDs without any behaviour or data attached. Data is added using Components and behaviour is added using Systems. See comp and sys macro for more details on those. 
ExampleIDItem = tuple[ecs: ECS, entity: Entity]
ExampleItem = tuple[ecs: ECS, entity: Entity]
Signature = set[ECSComponentKind]
The bitset that identifies what Components each entity has. For each entity, a Signature is stored within the ECS.signatureContainer array.

Procs

func `$`(entity: Entity): string {....raises: [], tags: [].}
Get a string representation of entity. Note that this representation cannot include the entity's label since it is store within the ECS. See inspect() for a string representation with the label included.

                  documentationComponent: DocumentationComponent) {....raises: [],
    tags: [].}

func getSignature(ecs: ECS; entity: Entity): Signature {....raises: [], tags: [].}
Get the set of ComponentKind that represents entity 
func getSignature(item: (ECS, Entity)): Signature {....raises: [], tags: [].}
func inspect(ecs: ECS; entity: Entity): string {....raises: [], tags: [].}
Get a string representation of entity including its debug-label. When release is defined, only the entity id is returned as a string. 
func inspect(item: (ECS, Entity)): string {....raises: [], tags: [].}
func newECS(): ECS {....raises: [], tags: [].}
Create an ECS instance. The ECS contains arrays of containers for every component on every entity. It also contains every Signature of every entity. The ECS is used to create entities, register them as well as to modify their components. 
func newEntity(ecs: ECS; label`gensym46: string = "Entity"): Entity {.
    ...raises: [], tags: [].}
Create an empty entity. This function creates an entity with a unique ID without any components added. Components can be added either using addComponent() (recommmended) or manually using ecs.<componentName>Container[entity.idx] = <Component>. If components are added manually, don't forget to manually manage the entity's signature by manipulating ecs.signatureContainer[entity.idx] through including and excluding ck<ComponentName> 
func removeComponent[T: DocumentationComponent](item: (ECS, Entity);
    t`gensym57: typedesc[T] = DocumentationComponent)
Remove DocumentationComponent from entity and update its signature by excluding ckDocumentationComponent 
func removeComponent[T: ExampleComponent](item: (ECS, Entity);
    t`gensym54: typedesc[T] = ExampleComponent)
Remove ExampleComponent from entity and update its signature by excluding ckExampleComponent 
func removeComponent[T: ExampleFlag](item: (ECS, Entity);
                                     t`gensym60: typedesc[T] = ExampleFlag)
Remove ExampleFlag from entity and update its signature by excluding ckExampleFlag 
func removeComponent[T: ExampleID](item: (ECS, Entity);
                                   t`gensym63: typedesc[T] = ExampleID)
Remove ExampleID from entity and update its signature by excluding ckExampleID 
func removeDocumentationComponent(item: (ECS, Entity)) {....raises: [], tags: [].}
Remove DocumentationComponent from entity and update its signature by excluding ckDocumentationComponent 
func removeExampleComponent(item: (ECS, Entity)) {....raises: [], tags: [].}
Remove ExampleComponent from entity and update its signature by excluding ckExampleComponent 
func removeExampleFlag(item: (ECS, Entity)) {....raises: [], tags: [].}
Remove ExampleFlag from entity and update its signature by excluding ckExampleFlag 
func removeExampleID(item: (ECS, Entity)) {....raises: [], tags: [].}
Remove ExampleID from entity and update its signature by excluding ckExampleID 
proc runExampleSystems(ecs: ECS) {....raises: [], tags: [].}
func setSignature(ecs: ECS; entity: Entity; signature`gensym47: Signature = {}) {.
    ...raises: [], tags: [].}
Set the signature of an entity to the specified set of ComponentKind. It is not adviced to use this function since other functions keep track of and manage the entity's signature. For example, addComponent() ensures that the added component is included in the signature and vice versa for removeComponent(). 
func setSignature(item: (ECS, Entity); signature`gensym47: Signature): Signature {.
    ...raises: [], tags: [].}
func toProperComponent(component`gensym51: NimNode): NimNode {.compileTime,
    ...raises: [], tags: [].}
Internal

Iterators

iterator queryAll(ecs: ECS; query: Signature): Entity {....raises: [], tags: [].}
Query and iterate over entities matching the query specified. The query must be a set of ComponentKind and all entities that have a signature that a superset of the query will be returned.
# assuming `Position` and `Velocity` components have been defined
# and `createECS()` has been called..

for entity in ecs.queryAll({ckPosition, ckVelocity}):
   echo ecs.inspect(entity)

Macros

macro comp(body: untyped)
Define one or more components. Components can be of any type, but remember that the type's mutability will be reflected in the way the component can be accessed and manipulated within systems.
import esasyess

comp:
  type
    ExampleComponent* = object ## \
      ## Note that in order to export you Components
      ## you, as usual, have to explicitly mark the
      ## type with `*`
      data: int
    
    TupleComponent* = tuple
      data: string
      data2: int
    
    EnumComponent* = enum
      ecFlagOne
      ecFlagTwo
    
    Health* = distinct int
    
    InternalUnexportedFlag = distinct bool
macro createECS(config: static[ECSConfig] = ECSConfig(maxEntities: 100))
Generate all procedures, functions, templates, types and macros for all components and systems defined until this point in the code. After createECS() has been called, it should not be called again. You can statically specify a ECSConfig with maxEntities: int that will determine the internal size of all arrays and will be the upper limit of the number of entities that can be alive at the same time. 
macro defineComponentAssignments(ecs: ECS; entity: untyped;
                                 components`gensym64: untyped)
Internal. 
macro defineSignature(components`gensym50: untyped)
Internal 
macro sys(components: openArray[untyped]; group: static[string]; system: untyped)

Define a system. Systems are defined by what components they wish to work on. Components are specified using an openArray of their typedescs, i.e.: [<ComponentOne>, <ComponentTwo>]. The group is a string to which this system belongs to. Once createECS() has been called, a run procedure is generated for every system group. These groups can then be called using ecs.run<SystemGroup>()

Systems are called using an item. The item is a tuple[ecs: ECS, entity: Entity]. Inside each system, templates are generated for accessing the specified components. If a component's name was Position, a template called template position(): Position will be generated inside the system's scope.

import easyess
comp:
  type
    Component = object
      data: int

sys [Component], "mySystemGroup":
  proc componentSysem(item: ComponentItem) =
    let (ecs, entity) = item
    inc component.data
    
    when not defined(release):
      debugEcho ecs.inspect(entity) & $component

createECS()
let
  ecs = newEcs()
  entity = ecs.registerEntity("Entity"): (Component(data: 42))
ecs.runMySystemGroup()

Templates

template documentationComponent(item: (ECS, Entity)): DocumentationComponent
Expands to ecs.documentationComponentContainer[entity.idx] 
template exampleComponent(item: (ECS, Entity)): ExampleComponent
Expands to ecs.exampleComponentContainer[entity.idx] 
template exampleFlag(item: (ECS, Entity)): ExampleFlag
Expands to ecs.exampleFlagContainer[entity.idx] 
template exampleID(item: (ECS, Entity)): ExampleID
Expands to ecs.exampleIDContainer[entity.idx] 
template idx(entity: Entity): int
Get the ID of entity 
template registerEntity(ecs: ECS; label`gensym65: string;
                        components`gensym65: untyped): Entity
Create an entity with a label and components. This template makes it very easy to instantiate an entity with predefined components. See newEntity to create an entity without components
